div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: DEATH
div.p: APPLEBY-- At Cairo on the 1nst., William Appleby, aged 68. Interred at Alexandria cemetery yesterday.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling. Price: One Plastre Tariff.
SATURDAY. MAY 27. 1905.
GOVERNMENT AND RESERVISTS.

At the recent meeting of the National Association for the Employment of Reservists and Discharged Soldiers it came out that daring a the last twelve months only nine of these men have found berths in the lower grades of the public service, with the exception of the War Office. The Duke of Connaught, who presided, and Lord Roberts, who moved the annual report, had full cause to censure such a discreditable condition of affairs. Year after year, official pledges have been given to set aside a reasonable percentage of depart mental employment for soldiers after the completion of colour service. Every effort would be made, the nation received reiterated assurance, to provide permanent careers for the rank and file, whether in the Reserve or passed through it. And the fulfilment of these Ministerial undertakings is what we have just stated ; the Post Office and the other chief employing departments, excepting that in Pall-mall, have actually contrived to make room for nine of the country's military defenders in a year! Lord Roberts stigmatised the miserable shortage as "most lamentable." while the Duke deeply regretted that the Government had not been able to give more employment to those deserving men. Last year, out of 15,006 applicants on the list, considerably more than half were furnished through its instrumentality with permanent berths. And what does that high authority, Sir Charles Sootter, say about the men thus scouted by jacks-in-office? The South-Western Railways is so thoroughly satisfied with the conscientious and intelligent way in which they perform their duties that in the last three years it has nearly doubled the number in its employ; 'they found from' long experience, "Sir Charles deposes, “that ex soldiers an steady, sober, honorable, and reliable."

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET.
VESSELS ANCHORED OFF SADDLE ISLANDS.
div.p: London, May. 26.
Reuter's Agency learns from Shanghai that 5 Russian volunteer steamers and 3 colliers. are off the mouth of the Yang-Tze, (Reuter.)
London, May 26.
Reuter's Agency learns from Shanghai that 17 ships belonging to the Baltic Fleet were anchored last night off Saddle Islands.: (R.)
ADMIRAL BIRILEFF STARTS.
St. Petersburg, May 26.
Admiral Birileff started for Vladivostok yesterday evening. (Reuter.)
WARSAW DISTURBANCES.
ATTACKS ON DISORDERLY HOUSES.
Warsaw, May 26.

Fighting was continuous during yesterday. Until now there are 8 killed and 100 wounded. The disturbances originated in an organised attack of Jewish Socialists armed with axes on the Jewish disorderly houses. Doors, windows and furniture were smashed. The fighting was most sanguinary : knives and revolvers were freely used. The police were passive spectators. (Reuter.)
Warsaw, May 26.
The demolition of disorderly houses, including elegant flats of the demi-mondaines, continues here to-day unrestrained. Christians are now participating. Similar action is imminent at Lodz. (Reuter.)
DEFENCE OF INDO-CHINA.
Paris, May 26
The Minister of Marine announces that two more submarines, four shallow torpedo-boats, and six torpedo gun boats will sail for Indonesia (Reuter.)
Paris, May 26.

The Council of Ministers has decided to complete the system of defence of Indo-China by the despatch in the month of August of two submarines, four shallow torpedo-boats, and six torpedo gun-boats. (Havas.)
THE PROPOSED JEWISH COLONY
GOVERNMENT OFFER TO BE REFUSED.
Vienna, May 26.

The Zionist Executive Committee decided to recommend the Basel Congress to decline the British Government’s offer of land a East Africa, because it is exclusively for pasture and unfit for Jewish emigrants. (R.)

div.head: KING OSCAR RESUMES. GOVERNMENT.
div.p: King Oscar has resumed the Government. (Reuter.)

div.head: BRITISH COLLIERS DETAINED.
div.p: Three British steamers loaded with coal for Hongkong have been detained at Moji by order of the Government. (Nrater.)

div.head: CRICKET.
div.p: Notts beat Kent by an innings and 83 runs. (Reuter.)

div.head: DERBY BETTING.
div.p: 10 to 11 against Cicero ; 3 to 1 Jardy ; 9 to 2 Velas ; 33 to one Rouge Croix, Silver Streak, Signorino and Llangibby ; 50 to 1 Standen, Shah Jehan, Gasure, Polymelus, and Thrush. (Reuter.)

div.head: Egyptological Work
div.p: The sons of the late President Henry Morton have presented seventy eight volumes on Egyptology to the New York Society Library.

div.head: Upper Nile Natives
div.p: At the last meeting of the Anthropological Institute of London Lient.-Colonel C. Delme Radcliffe gave a description of the customs of the Acholi natives of the Upper Nile.

div.head: Sudan Wells.
div.p: The Sudan Government has decided to dig a number of wells in the roads from Wad Medani and Gedaref, and also in the provinces of Kordofan. The cost is estimated at £10,000.

div.head: Big Deal in Cairo.
div.p: The details as to the purchase of Messrs. Sednaoui's business are, we understand, not yet terminated, and the negotiations as to thr price to be paid are still proceeding.

div.head: Railways is Syria
div.p: The Sultan has promulgated an Irade sanctioning the convention with the Syrian Railway Company, granting to the latter the right of extending its line from Hama to Aleppo.

div.head: Delta Railway Institute
div.p: The committee of the Egyptian Delta Railway Institute at Damanhour have organised a very attractive entertainment, which is to be given at the institute this evening, in aid of the Petite Asile d'Alexandria.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: 13 vessels passed through.the Canal on the 24th inst., 8 of which were British, 1 German, 1 French, 1 Italian, 1 Turkish, 1 Danish. The day’s receipts were frs. 413,730.73, making the total from the 1st inst. frs. 7,434,797.02.

div.head: Austro-Hungarian Agency
div.p: The Austro Hungarian Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General at Cairo Count Koziebrodsky, is leaving by the Austrian Lloyd steamer this afternoon for Europe. Count Stadnisky will act as Diplomatic Agent during his absence.

div.head: Railway and Caisse|Employes
div.p: The Council of Ministers has decided to place the employes of the Public Debt Commission and of the Egyptian Railways Administration, who are to be dismissed on the same basis in regard to pensions and indemnity as the Daira Sanieh employes.

div.head: Coal Imports
div.p: From the 1st January to 25th May 338,178 tons of coal were imported into Egypt. The Welsh districts sent 196,120 tons, Newcastle 68,434, the Scotch district 38,650, Yorkshire 21,241, and other district 13,763 tons. During the same period last yea 400,673 tons were received.

div.head: Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: Audran’s tuneful operetta Gilda de’ Narbona, which is quite new to Alexandria, was produced last night with a large degree of success. It will be repeated this evening. To-morrow afternoon, a matinee performance will be given of Fanfan la Tulipe, and is the evening Primavera Scapigliata will be produced.

div.head: Primitive Egyptians
div.p: Mr. Zaborowsk in a paper read before the Society of Anthropology of Paris, on the races of primitive Egypt, according to Messrs, Flinders Petrie, J. Kollman, and Chantr.-maintains, against Herr Kollman, the exclusively dolichocephalic character of the early Egyptian racial types, and repels the idea of a negro element.

div.head: Fire at Zagazig
div.p: On Thursday night a fire broke out in the house of Sadik Bey. Abaza, a notable of Zagazig. The furniture of the house was destroyed, but fortunately the confiagration did not reach the neighbouring houses, and the moudir and the commandant of the police succeeded in isolating the fire, the origin of which is unknown.

div.head: Alexandria Gouvernorat
div.p: A council of discipline is to be held this morning at the Gonvernorat under the presidency of the Governor and an inspector of the Ministry of the Interior to try Helmi Eff. Birzi, mamour of Moharrem Bey kism. Another council is to be held to morrow for the trial of Tewfik Eff., the chief of the administrative bureau at the Gouvernorat.

div.head: The Bedouin and the Smugglers
div.p: While a Bedouin of El Ababda was making his way along the Ismailia Canal, he noticed near a village called Nawa two natives with two camels laden with straw and beans on the way from Suez to Cairo. The Bedouin was suspicious as to the nature of the camels' load and he went to inspect the contents. The two drivers of the camels at once fled. 80 kilos of hashish was found hidden among the straw and the beans. The Bedouin took the camels to Nawa Market, where the police took possession of the hashish.

div.head: Maltese Benevolent Society
div.p: To-morrow will be the twenty-fifth anniversary of the foundation of the Maltose Benevolent Society of Alexandria,and the members of this excellent institution intend to have mass celebrated in the chapel of the Latin Cemetery at 9 o'clock to-morrow morning by the Rev. Father Joseph Vella, Maltese curate, for the repose of the soul of the late Salvo Grech Borg, the promoter of this society. After the mass a memorial stone will be inaugurated over the tomb of Mr. Borg. The advocate Mario Vella will afterwards pronounce a speech as president of the society. The poor families of the colony will receive alms and food to morrow.

div.head: Mohamed Aly Memorial.
div.p: An Egyptian correspondent, writing to a London Contemporary on the celebration of the centenary of Mohamed Aly, remarks, “The Municipality of Alexandria have proposed, as a public commemoration, the construction of a lunatic asylum. The idea has found but little favor in Egypt, where a work of the kind is regarded as solely the business of the Government, which, indeed, has already decided upon the building of a lunatic asylum, though not in the vicinity of Alexandria. It is unlikely that the Municipality scheme will survive the criticism bestowed upon it, and a more felicitous kind of monument will probably have to be adopted."

div.head: SAILORS AND SOLDIERS INSTITUTE.
div.p: Another very successful and most enjoyable concert was held at the above institute on Thursday evening, which, judging from the numerous encores demanded by the audience and so kindly granted by the performers, equalled, if it did not surpass, the former one held a month ago. The well-arranged programme, in which the vocal and instrumental performances were well balanced, was carried out in a most thorough style. The songs of Mrs.Gamble and Miss MunGavin were, as on the previous occasion, highly appreciated, and the pianoforte solos of Mrs. Gordon thoroughly merited the applause accorded to them. Miss M. K. Gibson's rendering of the “Intermezzo" from Caballeria Rusticana was something to be remembered, and was received with one long and continued call for an encore. Which was given in this talented lady’s best style as was also her other, item, with its encore. The mandoline solos of Professor Rizzitano were excellent, exhibiting taste and feeling, combined with faultless execution. Two novelties; in the shape of an imitation of church bell ringing, given by Mr. O. S. Heaton, and a masterly exhibition of club swinging by Gunner S. Hall, R.G.A., made a delightful variation in the entertainment. The recitation by Drummer Peace and the pianoforte solo by Private Russell well earned the praise awarded them, while Mr. Dodwell’s two songs and three encores proved the power of a good comic song, well sung, to amuse both old and young. The proceedings closed with a vote of thanks to the performers, and to Mrs. Lawrence for organising so successlul an entertainment; and although there was no formal vote of thanks given, yet we are sure that all present felt that the success of the evening was greatly enhanced by the admirable manner in which Major Gamble precided. The hall, which was prettily decorated with flowers kindly sent by Mr. John Ross, was well filled with an audience in which the military formed a good proportion, our now friends of the R. G. A. showing a good muster. Amongst those present we noticed Major and Mrs. Gamble, Capt. and Mrs. Gordon, Mrs. Moore, Rev. R. Wormell, Mr. and Mrs. John Ross, Mr. and Mrs. Acres, Mr. and Mrs. MunGavin, etc., etc.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Mr. Brunyate, Khedivial Counsellor, is proceeding to Europe for a trip to the Dolomites.
Prof. Dr. Ibrahim Pasha Hassan, honorary president of the School of Medicine, left for Europe this morning.
Mr. King Lewis, controller of the Direct Taxes Department of the Finance Ministry, will leave for Europe on July 1.
The Khedive has been graciously pleased to bestow the rank of Mirmiran El Rafia on the well-known notable of Sharkieh Province, Amin Pasha Ek Shamsi.

div.head: INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT OF ALEXANDRIA. IMPORTANT NEW COMPANY.
div.p: June 1 will he an important date in the history of the industrial development of Egypt’s commercial capital for on Thursday next the Rosetta and Alexandria Rice Mills Company will be launched. As is well known, Rosetta for many years past has been the seat of the Egyptian rice industry, and rice milling is in fact the only staple of that interesting but decayed old city of Lower Egypt. There are, however, many disadvantages in this site, for the railway communication with Rosetta leaves much to be desired, and the transport by sea and canal is antiquated, hazardous, and tedious. It is obvious therefore that Alexandria oil era far more scope for dealing with a commodity of such general importance to the inhabitants of Egypt and of the Levant generally, for the trade is developing rapidly every year.

Consequently an important group of capitalists, embracing many well-known persons of Alexandria, Trieste, and Marseilles, have combined together to start the Rosetta and Alexandria Rice Mills Company. The first step will be the erection at Alexandria of what is destined to be by far the largest rice mill in Egypt, and on Thursday next the foundations of the building will be laid. An advantageous site has been chosen on the Mahmoudieh Canal, between the Asphalte Company's works and Messrs. Abou Chanab's oil mills. The superficies of the site is about four feddans, and on this a large six-storey mill and two warehouses will be built by Mr. P. A. Gerakis, the contractor, after the design of Mr. Stienon.

The company intends taking over Messrs. Behrend’s rice mill at Rosetta, and the managing directorate will be in the hands of Messrs.Behrend & Company. The capital of the company is £60,000, all of which has been privately subscribed, and there will therefore be nopublic issue.

The machinery will be of the very latest description. It will be entirely automatic, and will be capable of turning out one hundred tons of cleaned rice every day, as against an average turn-out of a Rosetta mill of seven to eight tons per day. Every type of rice will be turned out, from the simple decorticated variety to the highly glazed finished article. The wants of the Egyptian fellah will to carefully attended to, and special attention will be directed to the manufacture of the “Maksous” or salted variety of rice, which native consumption specially affects.

When the Egyptian rice crop ends about March, the mill will turn its attention to Rangoon rice, which can be imported in either the rough or cleaned state as suits the mill's requirements. In the latter case the cleaned rice would undergo the glazing process.

The advantages which the new mill possesses are obvious, and the result will be that the rice trade, which has hitherto been concentrated at Rosetta, must necessarily find its way toAlexandria, and the last nail will be thereby driven in the coffin of Rosetta’s whilom prosperity to the benefit of Alexandria.
The mill is to be ready for work in about ten or eleven months’ time.

div.head: STATE RAILWAYS
div.p: The Administration of the State Railways has submitted for the approval of the Ministry of Public Works a proposal for the expenditure of the £700,000 granted this year by the Finance Department.

The proposal includes £150,000 for new locomotives, £130,000 for carriages, £140,000 for goods wagons, £75,000 for the renewal of rails and other material, £10,000 for the goods sheds at Djebel Zeitoun, £3,000 for the new construction of the bridge at Gabbari, £20,000 for level crossings and quays at Djebel Zeitoun and Gabbari, £7,540 for a new quay, £4,450 for embankments, £33,000 for improvements and enlargement of Cairo station, £2,000 for the improvoments at the stations of Zagazig. Mansourah, etc., £4,500 for improvements in the neighbourhood of Boulac Dacrour, £3,000 for sanitary installations, £22,000 for the construction of level crossings and the signaling department, £5,000 for the improvement of the Tantah station, £9,000 for improvements in the Benha and Galioub stations, £4,000 for the construction of huts for the workmen, £8,500 for a crossing bridge at Sohag station, £10,000 for expropriating the necessary land for the new Tautah-Zagazig fine, £5,000 for the land for the Achmoun-Delta Barrage line, £30,000 for doubling the line between El Wasta and Minieb, £14,000 for doubling the line between Palais de Koubbeh and Matarieh, and for railing on the sides of the line, etc., etc.

div.p: H. M. S. “Canopus" and "Goliath” sailed from Suez at 6 o’clock this morning bound to the China station.

div.head: CREDIT FONCIER EGYPTIEN. THE NEW SHARE ISSUE.
div.p: The Credit Foncier Egyptien has taken over the assets of the Daira Sanieh Company, Limited, for £9,900,000. The Credit Foncier Egyptien will make a share issue shortly for about £3,300,000 and a debenture issue for about £6.600.000. A syndicate has guaranteed the share issue at a price of 825 frames per share. Another syndicate will guarantee the debenture issue as soon as the percentage of the debenture is fixed. It is presumed that the new debentures will bear interest at the rate of 3/1/2 J per cent

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: On the conclusion of the Khedive’s visit to Windsor Castle as the guest of King Edward, his Highness will stay for about four or five days with Sir Ernest Cassel, at the financier’s town house in Grosvenor square.

div.head: CAIRO WATER SUPPLY.
div.p: A correspondent writes:—The Cairo Water Company try to explain away their shortcomings the fact nevertheless remains, that the town is on short rations of water, that the ice supply is far below the demand, and that the delivery of the same is made at all sorts of odd hours of the day. The company has certainly chosen a most inconvenient season to make any alterations whatever.

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: Bubonic plague appears to be regaining its hold on the country. Yesterday’s bulletin reports a case at Alexandria, Port Said,and Mit Ghamr, while one patient at Damanhour was discharged as cured. The case at Alexandria was that of a native boy living at Kom el Shougafa.

div.head: CLEARING OF THE SPHINX.
div.p: The second meeting of the committee appointed for the carrying on to the project for the excavation of the Sphinx was held yesterday afternoon at Judge Royle’s house. Judge Royle took the chair, and there were also present Mr. Courtenay Clifton, Mr. Allan Joseph, Prof. Dr Ibrahim Pasha Hassan,and Mr. Dow Covington.

The terms upon which the granting of the concession should be applied for came under discussion and it was decided that Mr. Dow Covington should make a personal application for a conditional concession. The application state the work shall be carried out by Mr. Covington under the direct supervision and with the cooperation of the Antiquities Department. It also undertakes that the one-half of the finds, which is the right of the excavator (the other half going to the Government) shall be distributed by the committee among those public institutions in whose names contributions are made and in proportion to the amounts so subscribed.
It is well to point out that any person may contribute to the excavation fond in the name of any public institution, but that no individual will be entitled to any part of the finds.

div.head: THE BRIGANDAGE CASE.
div.p: I am glad to be in a position to state that the united efforts of the Parquet authorities and of the officials of the Ministry of the Interior have succeeded in discovering the whereabouts of the valuables stolen by the brigands. They were found in a village hard by the desert that intervenes between the provinces of Fayoum and Beni-Souef. Six men implicated in the brigandage are now under arrest and energetic efforts are being made to lay hands on the brigand chief and other members of his nefarious gang. The Inspector of the Ministry of the Interior and the Moudir of the Fayoum are working day and night to unravel this case, and it is to be hoped that their efforts will be crowned with the success they deserve in bringing the ruffians within the meshes of the law.

div.head: FAYOUM LIGHT RAILWAY.
div.p: I fear that matters are not improving in the prospects of the Fayoum Light Railway. I was recently informed by a late employe of the company that there is a decrease of £10 per diem in the receipts of this railway, and he also declared that the present receipts of the line scarce suffice to pay the expenses. Of course I do not vouch for the truth of this information, but all accounts tend to show that the progress of the company is not rapid, nor can its future prospects be characterised as in any degree promising.

div.head: THE GHIRGEH SCANDAL.
div.p: The scandal in which Hasson Bey Wassil is accused of being implicated, has aroused great interest in the Fayoaum, where the Moudir is well-known. The general impression appears to be that he is innocent of any share in the Rifai affair.

div.head: THE CASSEL HOSPITAL
div.p: Sir Ernest Cassel's travelling ophthalmic hospital, which has been visiting the 1 Fayoum province, is to be transferred hence I to Damietta. Dr. A. Ferguson MacCallan, who is the ophthalmist in charge of the hospital, left this week for Cairo. His assistant, Tahir Effendi, leaves with the tents and all the hospital paraphernalia next week. During the stay of the hospital here no less than 12,402 visits have been paid by patients. Of these 637 were operated on for trichiosis, irridoctomy, cataract, and other ophthalmic complaints so common in this country. I used to visit Dr. MacCallan as a confrere, and I can state from my own experience that his success in the treatment of soft and senile cataract was most remarkable, and during his stay here he has alleviated a very large amount of suffering among the people. In the name of the inhabitants of the Fayoum I beg to thank Sir Ernest Cassel and the skilful physician in charge of his hospital, for the good that has been done in this province by the hospital.
The following passages from Dr. MacCallan's interesting report on his last year's work are worth quoting:—

“At the inception of the scheme, there was some doubt as to its probable success, and as to the readiness of the fellaheen to take advantage of it. All doubt has, however, been, set at rest by its immediate and complete success. There has never been the smallest hesitation on the part of the people to visit the hospital as patients, nor to submit themselves to whatever operation I have advised. The large proportion of women patients has been especially noteworthy. Both at Menonf and Damietta, the number of would-be patients has been much larger than the surgical staff of the hospital could cope with. It was no uncommon thing to find in the morning 200 people anxious to obtain admission, and the same condition of affaire now obtains at Galionb."

"All patients are treated free of charge, and are given bottles of drops and lotions for use at home when necessary. By far the larger proportion of the patients who attend the hospital have every appearance of poverty, and if there are more patients on any day than can be seen, the poorer patients are given preference.
Dr. MacCallan concludes his report with the following words :—

“The extension of the travelling ophthalmic hospital scheme throughout the country would, I feel certain; be as successful from an economic as from a philanthropic point of view. The number of inefficient workers due to the ravages of trachoma is enormous, and every child who now obtains relief at the camps is a worker saved from the ban of inefficiency."
Lord Cromer remarks as follows on this report:—

“One of the results of the absence of means of ophthalmic relief in the rural districts is the multiplication of quacks, who often do more harm than good to their patients. The establishment of the travelling hospitals will in some degree mitigate this evil, but the remedy so far applied has necessarily been only very partial. It is a well-known fact which is confirmed by Dr. Mac Callan, that a large proportion of the children who attend the Government schools require skilled medical treatment for their eyes."
And in regard to Dr. MacCallan’s conclusion his lordship says:—

"I do not doubt that Dr. MacCallan is quite right. In view of the very large number of subjects which call for the attention of the Government in this country, and of the further fact that the resources of the State do not admit of all these subjects being treated at the same time and immediately, I am always somewhat unwilling to state beforehand when it will be possible to take in hand any particular project for reform. I have, however, no hesitation in expresing a strong hope that before long it will be possible for the Government to provide means for extending the excellent system which, under Sir Ernest Cassel’s auspices has now been inaugurated.”

div.head: CAIRO MEDICAL MISSON OF THE C. M. S.
REPORT FOR 1904.
div.p: In reviewing the Medical Mission work of the past twelve, months, we, cannot but feel that 1904 has been a year of advance. A comparison of the statistics of the two last years shows marked progress in numbers. For instance, in 1903 we were glad to record 19,730 as the total number of outpatient visits to our Dispensary. Last year the number rose to 25,057. Again, the number of patients has risen from 864 to 1,767, while our total receipts in fees, etc. have been nearly doubled, thus enabling us to defray all expenses, save missionary allowances, and to end the year with a substantial balance.

With regard to spiritual results, which man cannot estimate, one can say that there have been evidences of a deepened spirit of enquiry and more earnest interest. Tangible spiritual results are few indeed, and were these our only guarantee of success, and were it not for the knowledge that results are in higher hands, it would be truly hard, having put one’s hand to the plough, not to look back.

Manifest tokens of God’s blearing, however, are not wanting. Some weeks ago we had a Sudanese, woman in hospital who was admitted for the treatment of a rare form of malignant growth on the foot. Sad to say, the disease has recurred repeatedly elsewhere, and will sooner or later almost certainly lead to a fatal issue. The patient was under Dr. Pains' care and I will quote his account of her:—

"She came here because, as she put it, she had seen, in a dream, someone come and say to her: Go to the English Hospital in Old Cairo. Very soon after admission she showed great interest in the Gospel story, and expressed herself as certain that the one she had seen in her dream was Christ Himself. She has been daily taught and learns rapidly with the full intention of being baptised, after she has put her affairs in order. She has some land she wants to sell, in order that it, as is most likely after baptism, she is cast out by her people, she may have wherewith to live. She quite recognises the probability of persecution, but says she will say to her son: “‘We have been on the wrong road. Christ has found me and put me on the right one. Will you come with me along it? Even if you won't, I must keep on it’”

Another encouraging case is that of a printer, a Cairo man, who had previously worked for our Mission, and had been influenced by contact with the missionaries and through the subject matter he had been employed to print. Strangely enough he also, while in hospital, dreamed that he saw Christ, who touched his hand and told him that he would soon recover. On waking, he aroused the other Moslems in the ward and warned them against opposing the Gospel, relating to them his vision. He was much impressed by the teaching he received, and the last report I heard of him was to the effect that he was doing all in his power to serve the Mission, in the face of considerable difficulties. He himself told me not many days ago that he was persuading some of the Moslems who work in the same press to attend the C.M.S evangelistic meetings in Cairo.

There are other cases too which might be mentioned. One is that of a Moslem woman who is now working as a dresser in hospital; another a patient on the men's side who was with us many months. For a time he showed real earnestness and it was thought well to give hint some private instruction over and above the teaching he received in hospital. Later, however, we were led to suspect that his keenness in learning was prompted by ulterior motives. However that may have been, I have recently heard from the catechist who visited his village that he is still taking an interest in the Gospel, and the Bible which was given to him when he left us is being read in his house.

While one writes one is reminded of a man who attended the dispensary for some time. I well remember him as rather noisy opponent of the truth, and on one occasion had to interfere on behalf of the catechist, who was the object of his attacks. There are few now who are more kindly disposed towards the mission than this man. He professes to believe in Christ and I believe his professions are genuine. May he in due time be given grace to confess them before men.

Other concrete examples of encouragement one might quote, but perhaps one of the most cheering signs in the work is the deep interest with which the Gospel message is received. There are always some in one’s audiences who seem to drink in the story of salvation, and one feels that the seed is falling on good ground. The fruit may be long in coming, but it is in the hands of Him who alone can give the increase.

Early in the year (1904) a temporary ward to accommodate thirteen men was built in the hospital compound, at a cost of about £70, which was derived from the balance of a sum given some years ago by Cairo residents for the erection of dormitories for Egyptian anemia patients. The ward has proved of the greatest benefit and has enabled us to get the greatest possible amount of use out of each bed in the hospital; as soon as a patient ia admitted,—supposing it is a surgical case— he takes up his abod: in the temporary ward until the day fixed for his operation. He is then transferred to one of the beds in the hospital proper; but as soon as be recovers from his operation sufficiently to enable him to get about a little, he returns once more to the so called "Noah's Ark”. There he stops until he is allowed to go home. So the hospital bed during the past months have been changing occupants very quickly; and supporters of beds and cots can be assured that their subscript XXXX are thus put to good account. (To be continued).

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: General Lord Grenfell G.C.B., G.C.M.G., who is already a Colonel Commandant of the King's Royal Ride Corps (the 60th), has been selected for the colonelcy of 2nd Life Guards, rendered vacant by the death of General Lord Chelmsford, G.C.B., G.C.V.O By virtue of this appointment, Lord Grenfell will become one of the three “Gold Sticks,” who take turns to be “in waiting” on the King.

The whole of Lord Grenfell's regimental service was passed in the 60th, which he joined as an ensign in 1859. He has held many staff appointments, including that of Commander- in-Chief in Ireland, to which he was appointed just a year ago ; and his war services include Griqualand West, in 1875 ; the Zulu War, 1879 ; the Boer War, 1881; Egypt, 1882; Nile, 1884-5 ; and Sudan, 1885-6-8-9. He has been seven times mentioned in despatches, and has received many honors and rewards for his services.
Lieutenant Colonel W M. Duckett, A.P.D., has been formally appointed District Pay master in Egypt, where he has been serving for some time.

When the Indian mail last left the 2nd Battalion King's Royal Rifle Corps had moved from Bareilly to Ranikhet. Lieutenant Colonel Walpole S. Kays, commanding that battalion, has been promoted brevet-colonel He has worn the “green-jacket” for over a quarter of a century and has the Ashanti Expedition of 1895 to his credit (star).

Lieutenant Charles Howard, Royal Berkshire Regiment, who recently figured in a case of alleged assault on the police in Dublin, has been removed from the army for absence without leave. It is understood that he went to Canada before his trial came off.

As soon as the first class cruiser "Carnarvon” is ready for commission she will proceed to the Mediterranean Station to replace the "King Alfred" which has taken the place of the "Aboukir" pro. tem. Captain Sir George J. S. Warrender, Bart, brother-in law of the Earl of Shaftesbury, has been appointed to the command of the “Carnarvon.” The "Carnarvon” is a cruiser of the "County" class.

The 9.2 gun, several of which were recently sent out to our coaling stations in the Far East, is a very fine weapon of long range and ballistic energy. It weighs 25 tons unmounted and throws a projectile of 380 lbs weight. This combined shot and shell is propelled to its destination by a charge of 63 lbs of cordite, which gives it a muzzle energy of 2,347 feet per second and an effective range of eight miles. At 3,000 yards the “nine point two" can perforate 18 inches of wrought iron. Half a dozen men can work it.

The projected manoeuvres of the Eastern Fleet—the East Indies, China and Australian Squadrons—have been cancelled and properly so. With Rodjestvensky's Pacific Squadron knocking about in the Far Eastern sees there would be every chance of another “regrettable incident," in which the gallant Russian gunners would hardly come off so well as they did in their historic encounter with the Dogger Bank Trawling Fleet and the phantom torpedo boats. There are some very straight shooting ships of ours in those waters.

A good deal of fun is still being poked at the Army Council on account of the minute regulations it issues on very trifling subjects. The fault lies in the publicity given to them in the Press, for many are matters of such minor detail that they need not go beyond the subordinates to whom they are addressed. Only that restless desire to comment on the action of the military authorities can explain why all the world should be told that nails must be extricated from worn-out mop heads before they are retained into store, or that the time-honored expression "By order” should no longer be appended to the instructions given out in the name of officers commanding by their staff. The energies of the military members of Council are perhaps running to waste for want of freer outlet. According to current reports the business of the War Office is greatly hampered and impeded just now by too disinclination of the supreme chief to give definite decisions on questions pending. So much uncertainty prevails as to the larger measures of reconstruction still in abeyance that small matters of very necessary routine are often neglected inconveniently.

If the public were not, at this time or day. ase-hardened to the exploits of the British War Office, there would be a tremendous explosion of national indignation over the official statement of the amount of stores and supplies "destroyed locally” in South Africa between 1899 and 1901. Not only does the loss in money amount to £293,937, but the loss is borne entirely by the public. Not a single firm of contractors is a penny the worse for all this fearful waste, and as to more than one-third of the total value, the War Office calmly declares that it does not know whence the goods came. Besides that proportion, there are other stone as to which the date of the supply “cannot now be ascertained." Why, in the name of common-sense, cannot the date be ascertained, and, therewith, the name of every firm that ever supplied a single cartridge or a tin of preserved meat? Such a confession as this is enough to make the most invincible optimist despair of any effectual improvement of War Office methods. To our mind it is simply inconceivable that the necessary information "cannot be ascertained;” but, if that be really the case, somebody else, besides the public, ought to be made to suffer for it.

div.head: GERMAN INTEREST IN EGYPT.
div.p: (From The “Berlin Post.”)

Business circles in Germany are beginning to direct their attention to Egypt more than ever. There is no doubt that during the last 20 years that country has made great strides. German imports from Egypt have risen from 13 million marks in 1894 to 57 million marks in 1903. while the exports from Germany to Egypt have risen from 7 to 23 million marks. It is not generally known that Egypt exports enormous quantities of raw cotton to Germany. In 1903 alone this amounted to 48 million marks. The increase of German traffic through the Suez Canal, on the one hand, and the high price of English coal on the other, have caused German shipowners to establish a coal depot at Port Said which has been a great success, and has considerably increased the importation of German coal into Egypt test year, 63 million tons were exported to Egypt, most of which was consigned to this depot Seventy German ships, of 150,000 tons, trade between this country and Alexandria, the chief port of Egypt test year the Norddeutecher Lloyd ran a regular service between Marseilles, Naples, and Alexandria, thus affording excellent communica- between Europe and Egypt. The great increase of passengers by this line has abundantly proved its necessity and justified its existence. A German bank, a branch of the Orient Bank established at Athens, is about to be opened in Alexandria, and the Hamburg-Amerika Line has arranged to start a service of six river boats on the Nile carrying both passengers and freight. All these arrangements prove, firstly, the existence of great German commercial interests, and, secondly, these new departures show that Egypt is a country of great possibilities, meriting more attention than it has hitherto received. In consequence of this new service it will be possible to open new German goods depots, and to form new commercial centres. This undertaking will be supported by the already large foreign trade, and the German concerns in Syria and Egypt will be able to lend each other a helping hand and give mutual support. And there are yet other opportunities for peaceful commercial enterprise.

div.head: THE SECRET OF THE WORLDS.
div.p: When we see what we have done and what we are on the point of doing, writes Manrice Maeterlinck in the "New York Tribune," it is not absurd to hope that some day we shall lay hold of that essential secret of the worlds which for the time being we have called the law of gravitation.
There is nothing mad in supposing that the secret of this sovereign force lies hidden within us, or around us, within reach of our hand.

It is perhaps tractable and docile even as light and electricity. It is perhaps wholly spiritual, and depends upon a very simple cause which the displacing of an object may reveal to us. The discovery of an unexpected property of matter analogous to that which has just disclosed to us the disconcerting qualities of radium may lead us straight to the very sources of the energy and the life of the stars, and from that moment man's lot would be changed, and the earth, definitely saved, would become eternal.

It would, at our pleasure, draw closer to and farther from the centres of heat and light, it would flee from worn-out suns and go in search of the unsuspected fluids, forces, and lives in the orbit of virgin and inexhaustible worlds.

div.head: AN UNHEALTHY LIVER OR STOMACH STARVES YOU.
DOAN'S DINNER PILLS CURE EVERY LIVER, STOMACH & BOWEL TROUBLE.
div.p: The greatest danger the General on the battle-field has to face, is the cutting-off of food supplies: it means the starvation of his troops, and ultimate disaster. In just the same way, your greatest danger is the failure of the liver and stomach to change your food into nourishment for the blood, bones and tissue.

This is why liver and stomach trouble is so serious ; it means that no matter how much you eat, you are being slowly starved ; every nerve and organ is being robbed of its' proper nourishment; the blood is poor and lacking in redness, the lips and cheeks become pale, the eyes yellow, the expression haggard. You grow thin and weak, feel heavy and list less. These symptoms are the digestive organs' cry for help, and Doan’s dinner pills should be used regularly until every sign of the trouble has gone, otherwise you will be in danger of anemia, constipation, chronic indigestion, biliousness, dyspepsia, and congestion of the liver. Doan's dinner pills are made from pure roots and herbs that help the liver, stomach and bowels, restoring a natural action and a healthy digestion of food. This medicine ought to be in every, home, and a does at once by any one who is unwell.
Doan's Dinner Pills are for sale by all chemists and druggists at P.T. 5 a box; or they may be had direct from the general agent for Egypt,—Max Fischer, Hotel du Nil Street, Monsky, Cairo.

div.head: UNDER THE MOSQUITO NET.
div.p: “As I laye a thinkynge" Ingoldsby

While there is much in the recent address of Sir Frederick Treves on “the physical effects of the use of alcohol" that may well be taken to heart and acted upon, I cannot help thinking that in some passages he rather overshot the mark, and made statements that he would find it very difficult to substantiate.

Take for example, the following assertion: "The great and laudable ambition of all, and especially of young man, to be 'it’ could not possibly be achieved if they took alcohol. It was simply preposterous to suppose that any young healthy person needed any alcohol whatever ; and, indeed, he was much better without the smallest amount of it"

It needs no elaborate research to find examples in the lives of eminent men that completely disprove this assertion, and justify the term reckless being applied to it. Two very prominent instances of men in every sense fit and capable strike me at once, Mr. Gladstone and the Earl of Shaftesbury, the one the most distinguished statesman of the 19th century, the other a man of equal prominence as a philanthropist .

Neither of those men were total abstainers. Neither must be judged merely by the physical results on their bodies of taking alcohol but as public men by the effect of their example upon those within the sphere of their influence, especially that of the latter, whose life-work lay among the poor and illiterate classes of London.

A few, years ago I made a careful study of Lord Shaftesbury's life, mainly for the purpose of trying to determine in my own mind the following question:— Great as the good achieved by his lordship undoubtedly was, would it have been still further increased if he had been an advocate of total abstinence from intoxicating liquors

The conclusion I formed was that instead of doing more good he would have done less, because he would have to a very great extent imposed limits upon himself, and raised up what would have in very many cases proved an impassable barrier between himself and the people he did so much to benefit.

No one would, I should imagine, seriously contend that, Mr. Gladstone in any way dimmed the brilliance of his marvellous intellect by taking a glass of wine with his dinner, or in the least degree lowered his high moral character because he was a strictly moderate drinker.

Another thing that impressed me in this address by Sir F. Treves was that it was limited to the effect that alcohol has on the system. One would almost fancy from it that alcohol pun and simple was imbibed and that it was taken without admixture with such other ingredients as malt and hops in ale, or grape juice in a glass of wine. The sense of proportion is entirely lost sight of, and it is simply classed with such well-known poisons as arsenic, opium, or strychnia. Is this fair? I think not.

In taking this line, however, the speaker simply followed that usually followed by propagandists, and it seems almost out of the question to expect fair and impartial treatment at their hands, of any subject of which they have undertaken the advocacy. It is always best to bear this in mind when estimating the value of the assertions made from various platforms—and pulpits.

But there are exceptions to every rule, and one of the most notable of these came under my notice in London a few years ago. An eminent Christian preacher, when referring to some of the sayings of Christ that are somewhat hard to understand, “turning the other cheek," “giving the cloke also," and so on, expressed his opinion that Jesus only did what other propagandists did, viz, overstated his subject.

This was a somewhat bold step on the preacher's part, but it is an extremely significant fact that advanced religious teachers are not afraid to grapple with difficulties, and look for reasonable solutions of them, rather than take shelter behind walls so many deem impregnable, (and which popular prejudice helps to make so), when the voice of reason makes itself heard in the attack on traditional belief.

So if the good people who devote themselves to philanthropic effort for the good of man- kind do overstep the mark, they do so in good company, and if Sir F. Treves did present a somewhat one-sided view of a great question there is every reason to hope that he may have effected a great deal of good, by bringing so prominently forward the value of temperance, and the fact that the consumption of alcoholic drinks is enormously in excess of what it should be.

The vegetarians, in my opinion, have a still stronger cue than the total abstainers, for in addition to the undoubtedly injurious effects of an excess of animal food, and the possibly ill effects (in some cases) of even a moderate consumption of flesh food, there is the hideous amount of suffering indicted on animals prior to their being killed, to be considered, apart entirely from the question of taking animal life to provide food for man.

The latter considerations carry far greater weight with me than the former. I have seen so much preventive cruelty, and road of so much more, that I feel persuaded that if the public in general were only better informed, and gave more thought to the terrible sufferings borne by the animals which furnish the meat-eater's daily food, the ranks of the vegetarians would be greatly swelled.

But the question of personal health is no trivial one, and when it is fully realised, as analysis amply proves, that far more nutriment may be obtained from vegetable than from animal sources, the much greater freedom from disease that the abstainer from flesh food enjoys as compared with his meat-eating fellow man will be better appreciated.

Many would-be vegetarians are under the impression that it is impossible to obtain the nourishment they require without eating animal food. They give the vegetarian system a trial, but from an imperfect understanding of the kind of food they should eat, and the proper proportion of heat, flesh, brain; bone and nerve forming foods, — in other words the want of a sufficiently scientific experiment,—they rash to the conclusion that the new system is unsuited to their requirements.

Those who have perserved and endeavoured to understand the conditions necessary to success, tell a different tale, and speak only of the benefit gained by the change they have made; but still it must ever be borne in mind that constitutions like everything else greatly differ, and that what is meat to one man is poison to another.

It is this great central fact that propagandists are so prone to ignore. They rash to the conclusion that what benefits one must be good for another, and although they are instrumental in effecting great good, they are too apt to lose sight of the great diversity of requirements to be found among “all sorts and conditions of men," — bodily, mental and spiritual.

To the man or woman seeking spiritual unfoldment, and who, in order to attain this end, is prepared to “mortify the lasts of the body," no better advice can be given than to seek by pure diet and clean living to bring it about. That it is possible to become at once, and without injurious bodily result a total abstainer from flesh food, alcoholic drinks, and tobacco, after a life-long indulgence in these habits up to beyond 50 years of age, I can, from personal experience, testify, while nothing could be more marked than the resultant quickening effects upon the mental and spiritual faculties. T. A.

div.head: ORIENTAL STUDY IN ENGLAND.
div.p: The Council of the Royal Asiatic Society takes up a very strong position when urging the necessity of bringing into active being a State institution for the promotion of Oriental study, it is certainly not creditable to a country ruling over more Asiatic subjects than all the other European and American nations combined that such studies can be much better carried on at Berlin or Paris. The report states that Anglo-Indian officers frequently take furlough to one or the other of those capitals instead of going to London, solely became the facilities for learning what they want to learn are so highly superior. There would be no lack of competent teachers were the Royal Asiatic Society's aspiration fulfilled ; we are amply supplied with Orientalists of the highest attainments. But, as in many other matters, England is satisfied with the arrangements which served well enough to keep her in the front rank when foreign competition did not seem likely ever to smirch her laurels. That being no longer the case, the Royal Asiatic Society should not appeal in vain for the founding and endowment of a London centre for Oriental study not inferior in learned competency to those at Paris and Berlin. As it would be of great benefit to India, directly and indirectly, the cost might be equally shared between the two Treasuries. Both spend freely enough on objects not nearly so much wanted for the renown of the greatest of Asiatic Powers.

div.head: TRADE IN THE LEVANT.
SYRIAN TRADE.
div.p: Reporting from Aleppo, Mr. ConsUl Barnham says The year opened under exceptionally favorable auspices. The rise in the price of cotton had brought much money into the country. There was the prospect of a fall harvest, with abundant pasture, and, consequently, a successful wool season. During the first six months, indeed, these hopes were fully justified, trade being unusually brisk, money plentiful and credit good. Then came a sudden fall in the price of cotton, which completely changed the aspect of things.

In Beyrout and Alexandretta important houses which had speculated in cotton stopped payment, while in Aleppo, though there was only one failure, many of the merchants were heavy losers through the failures which occurred elsewhere.
The farmers also and nomad Arabs lost heavily owing to the spread of cattle plague, and in a less degree from an outbreak of foot- and-mouth disease.
The export trade through Alexandretta shows an increase of £239,573. The import trade through Alexandretta shows a decrease of £264,321.

The importation of manufactured goods fell in volume 367 tons and in value £294,450. This was due to the fail in the price of cotton and to the existence of large stocks remaining over from the previous season. The market is still suffering from this state of things, and dealers are often compelled to dispose of their goods at wholesale prices. The imports of Manchester cotton goods declined 377 tons in volume and £219,378 in value. Other countries, however, show a similar decrease, notably Italy.

Three British lines—the Khedivial, Bell’s Asia Minor and Prince Line— have carried on a regular service during the year. The Khedivial Company is, I understand, about to establish another service connecting Constantinople with the porta of Anatolia, Caramania, Syria and Egypt.
The exports being £1,376,207, show a decrease of £424,167. The imports amount to £592,228, being a decrease of £37,222 on those of the previous year.

The exports to the United Kingdom and Cyprus have risen from £124,513 during the year 1903 to £303,382 during 1904, showing thus an increase of £78,869. There is a slight decrease amounting to £2,254 in the imports of the past year from the United Kingdom and Cyprus, the figures being £93,137, as against £95,381 for the year 1903. The general comparative conclusion is decidedly favourable to the United Kingdom. Although, in common with other nations, her share of the import trade has slightly decreased, the United Kingdom has easily out-distanced other nations in the increase of her share of the export trade.
THE CYCLADES.

In a report on the trade of the Cyclades for last year, Mr. Consul Cottrell states that the trade and commerce of Syria and the other islands of the Cyclades in 1904 showed unmis takable signs of steady decline in comparison with the preceding years, and the commercial depression still continues. The volume of trade of tire port of Syra represented a total value of £363,255 against £375,138 in 1903 and £124,363 in 1902. It is feared no hopes can be entertained of any substantial amelioration for the future, in view of the industrial resources of the neighbouring port of the Piraeus, together with the fact that the construction of railways in continental Greece is having a deteriorating effect on Syra, which in former years was a large distributing centre of commerce for nearly the whole of the Levant. Even the improvement in the money market last year, resulting from the exceptional fall in exchange, apparently engendered no stimulus in the purchasing powers of the local traders, although the question of the depreciation of forced currency has for many years greatly hampered the commercial dealings with foreign countries. Business in shipping circles again suffered severely last year from the persistence of few freights. As elsewhere, the available tonnage was a long way in excess of the demand, and the Black Sea and Danube trade, in which nearly all Greek steamers find employment, proved a disappointing and unprofitable market. Several vessels were in consequence lying idle in harbour for months at a stretch : even those that were engaged at current freights, except perhaps the few on time charter, barely recovered their working expenses, notwithstanding that Greek ships are run more economically than those under any other flag afloat. The Black Sea freights to Mediterranean and northern ports averaged 6s and 8s. per ton respectively, and outward freights from the United Kingdom, with coal only obtainable, were as low as 4s. 6d. per ton. Tho prospects also for 1905 are not very encouraging, and shipowners are becoming disheartened, after having invested so much local capital on this in preference to any other industry.
GREEK TRADE

Reporting on the Greek province of Thessaly for 1904, Mr. Consul Merlin says:-- There has been a small falling off in the number of British merchant steamers which entered the port of Volo in the year 1904 as compared with the preceding year, the total number being 33 vessels of 36,138 aggregate net tons register, as against 25 vessels in 1903 of 39,615 tons register. The vessels which arrived in the past year discharged 9,037 tons of cargo, of the total estimated value of £39,191.

In 1903 14,965 tons of similar merchandise were discharged from British bottoms of £46,839 total estimated value. Although the quantity and value of cargo of British origin brought in British vessels in 1904 is less than in the preceding year, the deficit is more apparent than real, as two foreign steamships, one Austro-Hungarian and one Norwegian, came from Cardiff bringing 6,450 tons of coal and patent fuel, valued at £6,200.

The trade in commodities of British origin in 1904 shows an increase over that of the preceding year, and may therefore be regarded as satisfactory under existing circumstances . It is true that the demand for articles of foreign manufacture shows comparatively little fluctuation from year to year, nor could it be reasonably expected to do otherwise, considering that Thessaly is a strictly agricultural province, the development of which must necessarily proceed slowly. All that can be expected under present conditions is that the proportion of British products annually imported should be maintained and show no falling-off.

Although in the aggregate a considerale trade is done in articles of British manufacturers, no commission agent or trader of British nationality is at present carrying on business in Thessaly, and the trade is therefore entirely maintained owing to the high estimation of the quality of the products which is very generally entertained throughout this district. I am frequently told that when an article of first-rate quality is desired the customer almost invariably insists that it shall be of British manufacture.

Within the past 18 months the gold voice of the forced paper currency has increased about 30 per cent. From a theoretical point of view this must be taken as a most satisfactory sign of the improved financial position of the country, but practically the effect locally has not been entirely satisfactory.

div.head: CRETE AND GREECE.
div.p: The “Figaro'' publishes an account of an interview which one of its correspondents at Canea has had with Prince George of Greece, who is represented to have declared that the only means of putting an end to the disturbed state of Crete is the union of the island with Greece. "The Prince would like,” it is added, a plebiscite of the inhabitants of the island, to be organised under the control of the Great Powers. He is convinced that a plebiscite would show that the only way of satisfying the national aspirations of the Cretan people is to grant them union with Greece.

In view of the great multitude of women suffering from some form of female disease and yet unable to find any cure, Dr. Hartman, the renowned gynecologist has announced his willingness to direct the treatment of as many cases as make application to him during the summer months without charge.

The treatment will be conducted by correspondence. The doctor will prescribe all medicines, applications, hyglenic and dietary regulations necessary to complete a cure. The medicines prescribed can be obtained at all drug stores. This offer will hold good only during the summer months. Any woman can become a regular patient by sending a written statement of her age, condition of life, history and symptoms of her derangements.

All cases of female diseases, including menstrual irregularities, displacements, ulcerations, inflammations, discharges, irritation of the ovaries, tumors and dropsy of the abdomen, should apply at once and become registered as regular patients. All correspondence will be held strictly confidential.

As is well known, Dr. Hartman is the president of the Hartman Sanitarium, an institution which has a department devoted exclusively to the treatment of female diseases. He is thus brought to see thousands of such cases every year, the most of whom return to their homes to be treated by correspondence. The principal remedy he relies upon in such cases is Peruna, which every woman should have who has any affection of this kind. Those wishing to become patients should address Dr. S. B. Hartman, Columbus, Ohio.

No one knows better than Dr. Hartman how much the women suffer with diseases peculiar to their sex. No one knows better than he does how many of them suffer with such diseases. Patiently, hopefully, wearily; and often silently, they eke ont a miserable existence, year after year.

No martyr in poetry or heroine in romance makes a more touching appeal to human sympathy than the woman burdened with the cares of a family trying to carry the extra load of some tormenting and ever present female disease.
Dr. Hartman's sympathy for such is unbounded, and his willingness to help them limited only to his power.

For directions everyone should read "The Ills of Life", a copy of which surrounds such bottle. Peruna is for sale by all chemists and druggists at five shillings per bottle or six bottles for twenty five shillings.

div.head: EGYPT'S WESTERN NEIGHBOUR.
ITALY AND TRIPOLI.
div.p: Rome, May 21.- Perhaps more than any other country Italy has periods of excitement over certain things, and now for about four weeks the whole attention has been absorbed by foreign politics, especially by the question of Tripoli, with revelations of all kinds, interpellations in the Senate interrogations in the Chamber, and discussions of the Foreign Budget; so that of those who are not accustomed to the nature of the country it might seem that the Peninsula is going to declare war on the whole world, while in reality in a fortnight all will be over. The question of Tripoli is, however, very interesting, as Italy, seeing herself threatened with being surrounded in the Mediterranean, succeeded in agreeing with England and France that the only part of North Africa still belonging to the Sultan should be left to her influence. Still, the will not occupy Tripoli, not desiring to imitate what Franco did with Algiers and Tunis, and England with Egypt, for many reasons, chiefly because, especially after the war with Abyssinia, there is in Italy a very strong party against colonial enterprise, and because a war with Turkey, no matter how easy, would represent the loss of several millions, which might upset that balance of the Budget of which the Italians are so proud. Besides, Italy at present is allied with Germany and Austria, has reestablished the most friendly relations with France, continues to have with England the traditional bonds, and will do nothing to come to a rupture with the recluse of Yildiz Kiosk. Therefore, the descendants of Macchiavelli have thought of a very curious policy, that of warning the other Powers that no one can go to Tripoli except Italy, who, however, will not use force to occupy it, except in case her preferential rights are threatened ; but wishes to establish herself between Egypt and Tunis in accord with the present owner of that territory, making Conntantinople understand that if the Turk fought he would lore Tripoli and a lot of money and men ; while, by coming to an understanding, he may preserve important privileges there, save all his men, and get a large indemnity or a considerable yearly income.

div.p: Two vacancies exist in the Sudan Medical Department for two qualified Doctors of Egyptian or Syrian nationality (Mohammedan, preffered).

Salary for the first two years L.E. 240 year with an increase of L.E. 24 after two years satisfactory service. And subsequent periodical increases according to the Regulations in force at the time being.
After one year's satisfactory probation anitable> candidates will be given the option of being placed the permanent list and coming under the Government Pension scheme.
The probationary year will count towards service for Pension.
Candidates should be unmarried, healthy, and under 36 years of age.

The appointment is subject to the general Government Regulations in force at the time being as regards leave travelling allowance and matters of discipline ; two months' leave is given every year as far as possible.

“Investments” introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the
SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are “Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them”; “Theory of Successful Speculation”; “How to start an Account” ; “The Advantages of ‘Call Options’”; “Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities” ; “How to Invest in Mines”; “American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees”; “The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments” ; “General Principles for Investors” ; “Rules for Investors in Mines”; “General Principles for Speculators”; “Stock Exchange Terms,” being a glossary for Market Operators; “Stock Exchange Parlance”; “Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money,” and “Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities.”
