div.head: OUR LONDON LETIER.
div.p: London, May 1O.

It is satisfactory to notice that Mr. Balfour's tactful speech on the defence of the country has excited no resentment in France. Every nation must in the necessity of things consider the possibility of war with every other' nation, and the taking of precautions against it is no evidence of unfriendliness. The Liberte among other journals, notes that Mr. Balfour was only speaking in the abstract in taking France as a test case. But it was done so delicately by the Premier that no other interference could have been made from his remarks.

Says the “Times" :— This country has no reason to be dissatisfied with the reception accorded abroad to Mr. Balfour's speech upon Imperial defence. Justice has been generally done to the purely defensive character of his whole survey of the situation, and to the total absence of anything that might savour, however remotely, of designs against the interests of any other country. Reasonable men every where are aware that our temper, our policy, and our large commercial interests combine to render us extremely averse from aggression or provocative adventure. For defence we can rely upon a united people at home, and upon the co-operation of our fellow-subjects all over the world, while invasion of the rights of others would be profoundly unpopular throughout the whole Empire. Indeed, it may be said that, if ever England should endanger the peace of the world, it would be by her weakness, not by her strength; by offering temptations to cupidity, not by exciting legitimate fears of aggression. A feebly detended British Empire would be the greatest of perils to the general tranquillity. The spoils would be too rich and too varied to be left to any single aggressor, and the division of the inheritance would involve the civilised world in sanguinary struggles. We have examples always before our eyes in Turkey and in China of the dangers to peace involved in the combination of weakness with coveted possessions. Our possessions doubt less excite envy in some quarters, and our free institutions are highly obnoxious to rulers who desire to impose their arbitrary will upou the millions who own their sway. But the instinct of awakening peoples is on the other side. Collectively they see in our democratic institutions the ideal of their political imagination and individually they find in the British Empire opportunities equal to those of Englishmen and infinitely greater than they could expect were our possessions to fall into the hands of those who most actively desire to take our place. The British Empire, like the United States, is open on equal terms to all men of whatever nationality who give fair promise of being decent citizens, and offers to all a degree of freedom and prosperity which they could not enjoy more folly, and in many cases would enjoy less fully, wore the flag that under which they were born.

The king of Spain is so pleased at the King of England's courtesy in appointing him a General in the British Army that he has conferred upon him the rank of an honorary Admiral in the Spanish Navy. Such exchange of courtesies symbolical of international friendship is peculiarly pleasing to the imagination of the Spaniards, and it will, therefore, serve an a proper prelude to King Alfonso’s approaching visit to this country. The young King is, furthermore, a Royal Celebs in search of a wife, or so, at least, one gathers from his reply to the address of the President of the Congress, in which his Majesty expressed his earnest wish for the speedy arrival of the "happy event for our country and my home" to which Senor Romero Robledo had referred. Inasmuch as “'tis love that makes the world go round," and royal weddings do not happen every day of the week, there will be no lack of speculation as to what the young King's visits to France and to England may end in. For the present, however, it would be premature to express any opinion as to the probabilities. All we know is that there is a crown waiting for some fair and gracious head to wear. May it speedily find a wearer.

Self centred as they have hitherto been, the Tibetans evidently know their own interest when; they see it. The welcome news comes that they are accepting the new condition of affairs under the British agreement in a peaceable spirit, and are even cordial in the relations with the British. So far as the people of Tibet are concerned, this attitude has characterised them almost from the beginning of our connection with them. Historians of the famous expedition tell us that the people were always agreeable except when the fear of the Llama and his mistaken advisers compelled them to adopt an offensive front. They were glad to welcome the intrepid strangers, seeing in them those infinite possibilities which men groaning under evil rule tore so quick to grasp. They even embarrassed the Englishmen by hanging too much on their skirts and refusing to depart. Now that the dread of punishment from their own vindictive authorities has been removed, it is only to be expected that they should continue to regard our temporary occupation with a friendly eye. For we bring hope to those who have walked in darkness for long years.

All sensible people will earnestly hope that I measures will be taken to put a stop to the proposed march of huge armies of the unemployed upon London. We really cannot afford deliberately to produce a serious public danger just because the Independent Labour Party happens to be in want of an advertisement, and the proposal is as much objected to by the Labour members themselves as by the representatives of any other class. The reason alleged for the suggested demonstration, namely, the supposed inactivity of the Government with reference to the Unemployed Bill, is mainly fictitious, and would, in any case, be quite inadequate. London has her own unemployed problem to solve, and no one but Mr. Keir Hardie would imagine that the solution could be made easier by pouring into the capital some thousands more of the out-of-works, many, perhaps most, of whom will remain to make the difficulty of obtaining employment greater than ever.

The delinquencies of motor-cars have already occupied the House of Commons two or three times lately in a desultory way. A more serious treatment is now proposed, and Mr. Arthur Stanley has given notice of application for an early date for the discussion, which will be pivoted on the vote for the Local Government Board. The move will not be a premature one. Excesses of speed are to form the text of the debate, but there are other points which may be thrashed out with profit One is a common yet very dangerous infraction of the rules of the road by "cutting corners.” Motor- cars, hansom cabs, and Royal Mail vans are the chief offenders in this respect, and of the three the first, by virtue of their speed alone, create infinitely the heaviest danger. Another matter which is almost certain to be discussed is the allocation of responsibility between owner and chauffeur. We might do worse than take a hint from Germany. There the owner bears the entire responsibility of anything that happens, irrespective of whether be himself is on the car or not. Such a regulation makes for caution bo‘h in the selection of the driver and in the methods of the employs whose master, thus penalised, will himself exact the utmost penalty for any dereliction.

What cannot fail to prove a most important development in the system of University education is to be introduced in the autumm at Princetown University, U.S.A. A special fund of £500,000 is being raised, and the intention is to devote this sum chiefly to the employment of a number of additional tutors, who will get into close touch with the men and give to each a real and personal attention. "An approximation to the praotice in English universities"— so an American paper innocently characterises the scheme. How ironical the words must sound to anyone with experience of the aforesaid practice! Perhaps one of the weakest spots in our own university system is to be found in the very point to which, America is about to devote its reforming energies. The haphazard way in which the young and probably not over-curious student is allowed to find out for himself the details of his studies, sometimes even the very list of the subjects which he is to take up, is, in many colleges at any rate, one of the things that render our university tutorial system a very whited sepulchre of emptiness. It is we who, once more, will have to learn from America, instead of the other way round.

If Mr. Kipling is to be believed—and we see do reason why he should not be believed—'it's Tommy this, and Tommy that, and Tommy, how's your soul?" According to a writer in a London paper, who signs himself “Corporal," it is rather the body of the private soldier which needs attention from the authorities. The King's uniform, he says, should create pride in a man. Indeed, he has not a word to say against it as a uniform. In his regiment, he declares, 'it is not the uniform we object to, but being obliged to squeeze ourselves into a garment which no man who cared for his health would willingly wear for five minutes." He proceeds to details. “How many 10st. 7lbs. civilians would care to be laced into a 30-inch waist, which is the average size for 5ft. 6ins. to 5ft. 7ins. soldiers?" Very few, we should be disposed to imagine. It certainly seems more than a little hard that the Army, which has done its share in making us Englishmen what we are, should not be allowed to breathe, it is the birthright of every Briton to be permitted to expand his chest. There may be some reason why thirty inches should be considered the ideal waist measurement of a military man, but we cannot imagine the reason. There is something in the idea of a British soldier being crammed into a uniform too tight for him which is repugnant to one’s notion of freedom. We hope that the authorities will stretch a point or two.
"John Strange Winter," (Mrs. Henrietta E. V. Stannard,) sends the following letter to the "Morning Post," dated May 12th :—

It may interest your readers to know that yesterday morning I saw a lady wearing a crinoline go by Albert Gate into the Park. It was not a mere stiffening about the hem of her garments, but was unmistakably a series of hoops of steel, apparently made on precisely the same model as those which went out with the siege of Paris in 1870. It undulated and it jerked, and as the wearer was a very fine woman with a small waist, and an extremely smart, rather large French hat, it gave an air of vulgarity almost incredible to believe. Meantime pledges against this hideous fashion are still pouring in upon me, and I shall be only too glad to receive more and more; as a proof that all women are not willing to allow themselves to be driven into the dangerous and the grotesque at the instance of commercial enterprise.

All users of the telephone must at one time or another have been struck with the possibility of danger of infection, from the telephone mouthpieces, particularly, in the various public call offices, and it is, therefore, very reassuring to have a report from the medical officer of health of the City on the subject. Dr. Klein, the eminent bacteriologist, has carried out experiments with the sanction of the Telephone Company with most satisfactory results. In none of the mouthpieces tested were there any tubercule bacilli present, and we are told that there is no real risk in the use of the public call offices.

For the last ten years the doctors have been searching for the cause of that increase in appendicitis which Sir Frederick Treves has described as the most remarkable medical phenomenon of the closing years of the last century. Now Professor Symes- Thompson has come forward with a suggestion that it is due to neglected teeth, became the same organisms which are found in the septic tooth are also found in the appendix. It seems curious, if this be the fact, that the disease should be prevalent among those classes whose care of the teeth amounts almost to a religion.

The first of the two theatres which are to adorn the island carved out by the new thoroughfares, Kingsway and Aldwych, is now finished, and will be opened to the public on Monday next. Splendid in itself, the Waldorl Theatre is really only an earnest of what is to be done architecturally on the imposing boulevard behind the new Gaiety. A comprehensive scheme has been adopted whereby the Waldorf and Mr. Hicks's theatres, with the big Waldorf Hotel which is to separate them, will be uniform in their classic design, and the whole facade in white Portland stone, softened by well-designed allegorical groups, promises to be one of the show theatre of London. The theatre now rising on the easterly side of the island will, indeed, almost be a duplicate of the Waldorf externally, although internal similarity, even if desired, will be out of the question, seeing that the County Council has decided that the Waldorf is to be the last three-tier theatre built in London.

As might have been anticipated, Lord Ave- bury's Bill for the closing of shops and prohibition of street trading on Sundays has met with a considerable opposition from the Jewish members of the community. The latter claim that if they close their shops on the Jewish Sabbath they ought to be allowed to open on Sundays. Nor is the argument confined to the Jews. It is maintained that unless some such arrangement be recognised everything would come to a complete standstill on the seventh day. There would be no taking a holiday if there were no trains and buses, for instance. A complete dislocation of this kind no doubt would commend itself to a section. At a meeting of the Lord's Day Observance Society yesterday, at least one reverend speaker expressed the view that leaving London for a day in the country on Sunday was a highly reprehensible act.

Scotland has suffered so long from the reproach of being a “drinking" nation that it is satisfactory to glean some evidence of a reformation in this respect. The report of the Prison Commissioners, just issued, states that cases of breach of the peace and drunkenness show a large redaction. The average number of committals for these offences during the previous five years was 38,848. In 1904 they were 32,959, a decrease equal to 15 per cent

A reviewer of books in a daily paper has been looking into the matter of the Society novel, and has come to the conclusion that, if the novelists are to be relied on, there is a marked scarcity of decent people in the fashionable world. In three books, professing to reflect with accuracy the manners and customs of the Best People, we find no fewer than nine of the characters (including the hero and heroine of one of the books) cheating at Bridge. To judge from the modern author, the standard of card-morality in Belgravia would appear to be lower than that in a Bowery saloon.

After its gigantic size, the thing that impresses one most in "Diplodocus Carnegii,” whose model is now to be seen at South Kensington, is the extraordinary smallness of the mouth and head. To keep such a huge body supplied with the necessary nutriment through such a comparatively tiny mouth, Diplodocus most have been eating all day long. He must have been a comparatively peaceful beast, for he can never have had time to do anything but eat between his intervals of sleep, and his brain was so minute that he can hardly have had the sense to outwit or outfight any serious combatant.

It is suggested that vegetation in prehistoric times may have been more nutritions than in our day, and that a greater amount of nitrogen may have been assimilated in a given mass of food. Size is the result of feeding, and it is certainly remarkable that these enormous animals tend to disappear with the lapse of ages. Even in creatures in which the mouth is small the rest of the body appears to have been well developed, proving that they bad time to produce this development by exercise, it may be that the power of the soil in producing vegetation has been to some extent worked out

div.head: NOTICE
SALE OF IVORY AND RUBBER, &c. AT OMDURMAN.
div.p: It is notified for general information that the Assistant Secretary, "Stores Section”, will sell by public auction at the Beit El Amana, Omdurman, on Tuesday 30th May, 1905, at 9 a.m. punctually, the following approximate quantities of ivory, rubber and cotton:-

Kantars 43 1/2 Aal No. 1 10 Aal No. 2 1 Kling 3 Bar more than 10 rottles 1/2 Bar less than 10 rottles 1/2 Khorda 5 Mashmus 13 Rubber 3 Cotton ginned 2 1/2 Cotton with seed 16 Cotton seed.> 43 1/2 Aal No. 1 10 Aal No. 2 1 Kling 3 Bar more than 10 rottles 1/2 Bar less than 10 rottles 1/2 Khorda 5 Mashmus 13 Rubber 3 Cotton ginned 2 1/2 Cotton with seed 16 Cotton seed.

The ivory will be sold in suitable lots at the rate of so much per kantar. Immature ivory acquired under the Section 17 of the Ordinance for the Preservation of Wild Animals and Birds 1903 is sold under condition that same is not resold in the Sudan and must be exported ex-Sudan within one month from date of purchase and a permit will be issued at time of purchase.

Ten per cent of the value must be paid by the purchaser at the conclusion of the auction and the balance within 5 days from the above date after which period it will remain at purchaser’s risk and subject to a demurrage charge of 100 milliemes for each kantar per diem until whole stock is removed.
None of the articles sold can be removed before the whole of the purchase money has been paid.
The Government does not bind itself to accept the highest or any offer.
Signed: D. K. B. Hall, Kaimakam, Assistant Secretary "Stores." Khartoum, 10/5/05. 25,994-7A-3
